r4tune joined #xwiki at 19:52  
MartinCleaver joined #xwiki at 19:57  
abusenius joined #xwiki at 20:12  
degro joined #xwiki at 20:14  
degro - (20:14): hello everybody  
degro - (20:15): does anyone have a clue upon how to get the currently inspected element in either firebug or the webkit dom inspector?  
degro - (20:15): with javascript, of course  
r4tune - (20:17): what do you mean  
r4tune - (20:17): how to get the currently inspected element  
r4tune - (20:17): you mean detect someone using it?  
r4tune - (20:18): also does xwiki support "tags" ?  
degro - (20:19): I mean returning the currently selected HTMLElement with javascript - I was wondering if firebug altered the dom in such a way in order to retain the inspected element in the global javascript scope  
degro - (20:19): because I couldn't find anything like this  
MartinCleaver left at 20:20 (Read error: Operation timed out  
cjdelisle - (20:20): r4tune: Yes tags are supported.  
degro - (20:20): I knew Firebug added a class or something similar to the html node, but I didn't see any firebug-specific alteration in the DOM today :)  
cjdelisle - (20:20): !search tag application  
r4tune - (20:21): i really wish it was written in python heh  
degro - (20:21): http://code.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Applications/TagApplication :)  
degro left #xwiki at 20:21  
degro joined #xwiki at 20:21  
cjdelisle - (20:21): You can write python into xwiki with the {{python}} macro.  
degro - (20:22): 8-)  
MartinCleaver joined #xwiki at 20:22  
r4tune - (20:22): that is cool.  
r4tune - (20:22): very cool  
cjdelisle - (20:22): Lets try this search thing again...  
degro - (20:22): http://code.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Macros/PythonMacro  
degro - (20:22): :D  
cjdelisle - (20:22): !search scripting guide  
cjdelisle - (20:23): #3 is informative about the different languages which you can use.  
cjdelisle - (20:24): "get the currently inspected element in either firebug or".. What do you mean by "currently inspected"?  
degro - (20:25): you know the "inspect" feature of dev panels: you click the htmlelement and it gets highlighted  
degro - (20:25): I want to get that element through javascript  
r4tune - (20:25): i think i'm sold  
cjdelisle - (20:25): :)  
cjdelisle - (20:26): Click the html element and it gets highlighted? This is a feature of firebug?  
r4tune - (20:26): does it with webkits gear too  
cjdelisle - (20:27): I can't help with webkit stuff but I use firebug.  
r4tune - (20:27): they do the same job  
cjdelisle - (20:28): noscript > \*  ;)  
degro - (20:28): there is a global variable declared by firebug: console  
degro - (20:28): but it doesn't hold any information about the currently selected node  
degro - (20:28): unfortunately  
cjdelisle - (20:28): If you go to "inspect html" doesn't it highlight the corresponding line?  
degro - (20:29): that's not what I need  
degro - (20:29): firebug works just fine  
degro - (20:29): I want access to firebug's data  
degro - (20:29): through scripting  
degro - (20:29): (that if it's even possible)  
cjdelisle - (20:30): Firebug runs in a protected section of firefox, I don't think it can be hacked from inside of web page javascript code.  
degro - (20:30): um... it wouldn't harm it if you would have read-only access  
degro - (20:31): anyway. I shall further research  
cjdelisle - (20:31): Maybe they provide an api to access it but I know the code \_can\_ be protected from your script.  
r4tune - (20:33): why do you want to know if someone is running firebug element inspector out of curiosity?  
MartinCleaver left at 20:34 (Ping timeout: 264 seconds  
degro - (20:38): it is me who's running the firebug inspector. I'm trying to get() what I personally clicked on from javascript  
r4tune - (20:41): interesting

sburjan` - (22:17): dada  
r4tune - (22:18): well  
r4tune - (22:18): i been trying for half an hour to do it  
r4tune - (22:18): firebug makes lots of modifcations to the dom  
r4tune - (22:19): and i made moz write the whole html dom to disk  
r4tune - (22:19): but there is nothing in there that will let you know what element it selected i can see  
degro - (22:19): hm  
degro - (22:19): thanks for trying that  
Enygma` joined #xwiki at 22:19  
degro - (22:20): too bad it doesn't have anything to pinpoint the selected element  
lucaa left at 22:26 (Ping timeout: 276 seconds  
r4tune - (22:27): firebugIgnore,addEventListener,constructor,querySelector,querySelectorAll,scrollWidth,clientLeft,clientHeight,clientWidth,clientTop,getClientRects,getBoundingClientRect,getElementsByClassName,mozMatchesSelector,baseURI,textContent,compareDocumentPosition,getUserData,isSameNode,lookupNamespaceURI,setUserData,lookupPrefix,isDefaultNamespace,isEqualNode,dispatchEvent,removeEventListener,style,contentEditable,offsetParent,innerHTML,offsetLeft,offsetTop,  
r4tune - (22:27): offsetHeight,offsetWidth,className,id,title,tagName,removeAttributeNS,removeAttribute,getAttribute,getElementsByTagName,setAttribute,getElementsByTagNameNS,hasAttributeNS,setAttributeNS,hasAttribute,getAttributeNS,nextSibling,firstChild,prefix,nodeValue,childNodes,nodeName,namespaceURI,previousSibling,nodeType,localName,lastChild,ownerDocument,parentNode,attributes,appendChild,cloneNode,normalize,hasChildNodes,insertBefore,replaceChild,removeChild,  
r4tune - (22:27): hasAttributes,isSupported,ELEMENT\_NODE,ATTRIBUTE\_NODE,TEXT\_NODE,CDATA\_SECTION\_NODE,ENTITY\_REFERENCE\_NODE,ENTITY\_NODE,PROCESSING\_INSTRUCTION\_NODE,COMMENT\_NODE,DOCUMENT\_NODE,DOCUMENT\_TYPE\_NODE,DOCUMENT\_FRAGMENT\_NODE,NOTATION\_NODE,getAttributeNode,setAttributeNode,removeAttributeNode,getAttributeNodeNS,setAttributeNodeNS,lang,dir,align,tabIndex,draggable,blur,focus,spellcheck,getFeature,DOCUMENT\_POSITION\_DISCONNECTED,DOCUMENT\_POSITION\_PRECEDING,DOCUMENT\_  
r4tune - (22:27): POSITION\_FOLLOWING,DOCUMENT\_POSITION\_CONTAINS,DOCUMENT\_POSITION\_CONTAINED\_BY,DOCUMENT\_POSITION\_IMPLEMENTATION\_SPECIFIC,scrollTop,scrollLeft,scrollHeight,firstElementChild,lastElementChild,previousElementSibling,nextElementSibling,childElementCount,children,classList  
r4tune - (22:27): oops  
r4tune - (22:28): sorry  
r4tune - (22:28): it makes a div with id \_firebugConsole  
r4tune - (22:29): those are the methods on it, i tried to paste to leafpad  
sdumitriu - (22:29): degro: I'm sure Firebug leaves some traces, since GMail can detect when firebug is active  
r4tune - (22:29): it's easy to detect  
r4tune - (22:29): what's not easy to detect is detecting which element it has selected with its inspector  
r4tune - (22:29): if there is a div with id \_firebugConsole  
r4tune - (22:29): firebug exists  
degro - (22:29): yes  
degro - (22:29): indeed  
r4tune - (22:30): there are other things which make window.console too  
degro - (22:30): what I'm trying to do is integrating firebug into an application  
r4tune - (22:30): so thats more reliable to detect just firebug  
degro - (22:30): but then again, I could listen myself to the mouseover events and remember the clicked element  
sdumitriu - (22:31): I doubt you get mouseover events  
degro - (22:31): without need firebug at all  
degro - (22:31): with prototype I do  
sdumitriu - (22:31): Since no mouseover effects happen when selecting an element  
degro - (22:31): it cross-browser-ises events afaik  
sdumitriu - (22:31): Not even the default :hover  
sdumitriu - (22:31): Oh, you mean outside Firebug  
degro - (22:31): yes  
degro - (22:31): independently  
sdumitriu - (22:32): What exactly do you want to do?  
degro - (22:32): select elements to create a configuration object for a tooltip  
degro - (22:32): I want to create an "application tour creator" application in xwiki  
degro - (22:32): to remember document coordinates and display tooltips accordingly in pages containing those objects  
sdumitriu - (22:33): Aha  
sdumitriu - (22:33): Nice  
degro - (22:33): actually thinking of proposing for integration in xe  
degro - (22:34): through a jsx  
degro - (22:34): but first gotta build it haha  
r4tune - (22:35): if yo really want to detect it  
r4tune - (22:35): what you can do is look at firebug source code  
degro - (22:35): hm  
degro - (22:35): yeah  
degro - (22:35): I'd rather do it myself with javascript  
degro - (22:36): it's not difficult  
degro - (22:36): firebug lite does it with js, too  
r4tune - (22:36): i think i misunderstand i thought you wanted to know which element firebug was inspecting  
degro - (22:36): either that or replicating the element selection behaviour with javascript if needed  
degro - (22:36): :)  
degro - (22:36): and I'll go the hard way  
abusenius joined #xwiki at 22:37  
MartinCleaver left at 22:38 (Ping timeout: 276 seconds  
lucaa joined #xwiki at 22:38  
r4tune - (22:44): im loving this xwiki  
r4tune - (22:45): it's only for me on my local hd  
r4tune - (22:45): so i downloaded your zip and go thing  
r4tune - (22:45): it's great  
r4tune - (22:45): i might export the IT notes to web later  
r4tune - (22:45): too cool for school  
degro - (22:45): glad you like it  
degro - (22:45): I enjoy it myself  
degro - (22:45): I script it :)  
degro - (22:46): groovy rocks  
lucaa left at 22:48 (Ping timeout: 240 seconds  
r4tune - (22:52): do you have anything built in to mark a section of text as code or a suggestion of how i would go about doing that?  
sdumitriu - (22:53): degro: You can listen to mouseover events on the body element, normally all events should bubble up  
sdumitriu - (22:53): r4tune: {{code}}var x = 1 {{/code}}  
sdumitriu - (22:53): !search codemacro  
sdumitriu - (22:53): CodeMacro20 should be the one you're looking for  
sdumitriu - (22:54): Aren't you using the WYSIWYG editor?  
r4tune - (22:54): yes I am  
sdumitriu - (22:54): There's the insert macro feature which lists available macros  
r4tune - (22:54): but i switched to source todo that  
r4tune - (22:54): ahh cool  
r4tune - (22:55): can i hint which language it is?  
sdumitriu - (22:55): Yes  
sdumitriu - (22:55): Normally it tries to autodetect, but that slows down the rendering a bit, and it doesn't always find the right thing  
sdumitriu - (22:55): Though I don't know which languages are supported  
sdumitriu - (22:56): You can try it  
r4tune - (22:56): only a few, but i will specify python anyway  
r4tune - (22:56): when i get more into it I can extend it to highlight python  
r4tune - (22:56): aww  
r4tune - (22:56): it says unknown macro if i do code:python  
sdumitriu - (22:57): It should support python, since it's implemented using Python's Pygments library  
sdumitriu - (22:57): No, it's {{code language="python"}}  
r4tune - (22:58): this rocks :D  
r4tune - (23:06): if i search for codemacro in the search box of my wiki it displays the same page 4 times, that's a bug right?  
sdumitriu - (23:07): Not quite  
sdumitriu - (23:07): It's a small bug  
sdumitriu - (23:07): It returns one entry for each translation of the page  
r4tune - (23:09): can you put comments in the wiki markup somehow? XWiki Syntaxes doesn't mention it  
sdumitriu - (23:09): Not directly  
sdumitriu - (23:10): Wiki comment syntax should come in 2.5 or 2.6  
r4tune - (23:10): like I want to get rid of "Recent changes" on my main page but I might want it back later so i wish to comment... i'd have to do like html macro and comment in there?  
sdumitriu - (23:10): You can comment inside scripting macros  
r4tune - (23:10): whats the comment token  
r4tune - (23:10): /  
r4tune - (23:10): /  
r4tune - (23:10): er  
sdumitriu - (23:10): Like {{velocity}} #\* This is a comment \*# {{/velocity}} or {{html}} <!-- html comment --> {{/html}}  
r4tune - (23:11): Now all i need to do is put vim in the wiki editor  
r4tune - (23:11): heh  
degro - (23:12): there's a firefox extension from opening textarea content into an editor you specify  
degro - (23:12): "it  
degro - (23:12): "it's all text"  
degro - (23:12): \*  
degro - (23:12): mm  
r4tune - (23:12): maybe there one for that too  
degro - (23:12): there's also one for chrome  
r4tune - (23:12): or i just port the firefox one  
r4tune - (23:12): sweet  
degro - (23:12): but you have to install a server  
degro - (23:13): chrome doesn't have access to the filesystem  
r4tune - (23:13): irritating but if it gotta be done...  
degro - (23:13): like firefox  
degro - (23:13): at least on linux  
r4tune - (23:13): got a link?  
degro - (23:13): 1sec  
Enygma` left at 23:13 (Ping timeout: 272 seconds  
degro - (23:14): http://psung.blogspot.com/2010/01/edit-with-emacs-chrome-extension.html  
degro - (23:14): there is this one  
degro - (23:14): which you could probably hack  
r4tune - (23:15): cool thanks
